name: Hydrology
description: Criteria related to the movement, distribution, and quality of water in the Great Lakes.

name: Watershed Influence
description:
Watershed influence is the combined potential land influence from tributaries
and shoreline interfluves. The watershed influence class breaks are:
  • minimal (<120 km2; stream order 1-3)
  • small (121-2,500 km2; stream order 4-5)
  • medium (2,501-7,500 km2; stream order 6)
  • large (>7,500 km2; stream order 7)

name: Temperature Energy
description: Data relating to the temperature of the water.

name: Cumulative degree-days
description:
Cumulative degree-days (CDD) is a measure of annual heat accumulation
in the Great Lakes and an indicator of the thermal regime. CDD classes are:
  • <3,000 degree-days
  • 3,000-3,900 degree-days
  • >3,900 degree-days
    • based on breaks in fish thermal requirements

name: Ice cover duration (days)
description:
Ice cover duration derived from ice cover data obtained from the Great Lakes
Ice Atlas and NOAA Great Lakes Environmental Research Laboratory.

name: Geomorphology
description: Criteria related to topographic and bathymetric features.

name: Substrate
description:
Substrate is the bottom material covering the Great Lakes which ranges from clay
and silt to boulders. Substrate descriptions have been aggregated into three
common classes: fine, coarse, and very coarse/hard.

name: Depth (m)
description:
These Depth classes represent different hydraulic and hydrogeomorphic conditions
relative to energy and temperature (Wang et al, 2015). Depth classes include
  • Coastal (0-3m)
  • Shallow nearshore (3-5 m)
  • Deep nearshore (5-15 m)
  • Very shallow offshore (15-30 m; only in Lake Erie)
  • Shallow offshore (30-100 m)
  • Deep offshore (>100m)

name: Shoreline classification
description: Classification of the great lakes shoreline.

name: Shoreline sinuosity
description:
Shoreline sinuosity is the degree of shoreline meandering and is an indicator of habitat complexity.
The sinuosity was broken into three classes (low, medium, high) using the natural breaks method.

name: Submerged aquatic vegetation
description:
Submerged aquatic vegetation is aquatic vegetation that is typically submerged below
surface water levels. The data is derived remotely sensed imagery and field verified from
Michigan Tech Research Institute (http://www.mtri.org/cladophora.html)

name: Mechanical
description: Criteria related to movement of the water within the Great Lakes.

name: Upwelling
description: The cyclic motion of colder water towards the surface as warmer water sinks. Low represents X degree of upwelling, Medium represents Y degree, High represents Z degree.

name: Circulation (m/s)
description: Rate at which the water is flowing offshore. Low is X m/s, Moderate is Y m/s, and High is Z m/s.
